title: How to play my phone's music through the car radio - Quora

response.answer_text: You can play music in a few ways: Bluetooth connection, and/or USB cable to charge and/or connect, or… -*1.5: a flash drive with your music library on it. some cars have wireless phone charging stations built in (higher trim levels). Usually you can control the music from the unit’s face, steering wheel (if equipped), which is most convenient and safer.another variation would be a Bluetooth USB adapter that would plug into your Receiver’s USB port and pick up your phone’s bluetooth, if you have a head unit without built in bluetooth.Aux(illary) cable. Easy enough with good sound. (I recommend a retractable or shorter cable)Fm transmitter to your fm radio. This can be trouble or static-y if there are local stations with similar or same frequency and they take up a 12v DC (cigarette lighter).Some, not many, can do Wi-Fi/cell tower, or satellite connections, or the cloud.With one of the above, you can do it through basic “music” library, Spotify, pandora, YouTube, etc apps through your phone.Oh and if you have a tape deck and headphone (aux 3.55 mm) jacking your phone, you can get crummy music through a cassette tape adapter. I Don’t recommend doing this though unless you have a really old deck. It costs as much, or more than the other options, has noticably lesser quality, and cords will be a PITA and constantly gets snagged on things like the gear shifter, cups, seatbelts, or even you!You must have an aux jack, usb port/jack or FM radio/tape deck on you receiver unit for any of the above to connect with, or built in Bluetooth. Thats about it. The easiest is blue tooth. Or USB. The worst is tape deck adapter. Some units may even have RCA/audio-(video) red/white/(yellow) jacks but that’s usually for amplifiers, and usually an out port, not an in port. These can also (if capable and correct) be used for additional screens for dvds, speakers, and other media, but nothing to do with phones. *Possibilities I didn’t mention and absolutely not worth the mind bending hassle of connectivity and hard to find adaptors or just plain obsolete: s-video, aux-to-rca/rca-to-aux, rf infrared laser, and HDMI (unless you have a blue ray player built in, and a hub/port on your phone ). Oh, That phone size slot is a slot for a cassette tape or maybe even an 8-track… not a phone btw. Seriously go for bluetooth or usb, or update your deck if you don’t have it altready. Some even have a hard drive or SD card slots for gigs of memory ( or gps). Rock on

Depends on the radio you have. I’m guessing it doesn’t have BlueTooth streaming, or you likely wouldn’t be asking. If it has an Aux input, you can use that via the phone’s headphone out or a USB to audio & 12v charge cable if one is available for your phone. Some cars don’t have an immediately visible Aux, but creative shops can access one for you. Lastly, you can use an FM modulator, to convert the phone’s output to an FM radio signal, and feed that in through your radio’s FM tuner. This is the least desirable way, as, at best, FM stops at 15kHz (chops off some of the really high frequencies), has poor dynamic range, and poor stereo separation. So you’re at the mercy of how good your modulator is AND how good your radio’s FM tuner is. And you have to find an empty FM frequency, which may change as you drive (for you out there old enough to remember, this is like when we piped our VCR or AtariVision through our {old, 4:3 squarish, tube!} TV’s coaxial antenna input and used channel 3). Wireless FM mods add in their limited transmission strength so often don’t even work as well as wired ones. It would be helpful to know which car you have (including trim level of stock radio, as there may be 2–3 offerings for a given vehicle) and what phone you have. Cuts down on a lot of the “ifs” for the people answering.
